[davido], [localtime://2006-11-01 19:37:14]
Sounds good. Q&AEditors: Add to this list when you take over a category for cleanup, and mark it done when you're ready to release your evil grip from the polished bones of its once rotten and decaying remains. ;)

The master list has been moved to the top of this wiki -- [jdporter]

And [jdporter] is right: be aggressive. Make it count. Questions should be good questions, answers should be good answers. Rewording and rephrasing is fine. SoPWify the lousy questions, or restate them if they're worth salvaging. Delete unworkable and bad answers. If you find the absence of a good question or answer, either ask it yourself, answer it yourself, or maybe post a node in [PerlMonks Discussion] with a list of possible questions and answers that others may wish to contribute.

When in doubt, seek clarification here in our wiki.

One more thing while I'm thinking about it. There's no real good reason to attach editor attribution to the nodes you've worked on. I would even go so far as to remove any you find, or better yet, put any existing attributions (and your own if you feel it's necessary) into . It's not that important to leave a fingerprint; [QandAEditors|we] own whatever happens here.

[tye], [localtime://2005-09-07 22:22:33]
I agree that it is too soon for Perl6 answers to Perl5 questions in CatQ+A. It may not be too soon for a few Perl6 questions, which, of course, should get Perl6 answers.

Eventually (probably pretty soon, since we have working implementations of much of Perl6) the specification for most of Perl6 will be finalized (it appears to still be fluxuating in interesting ways -- from my very-outside perspective), and it will be appropriate for Perl6 answers to appear for general questions.

As with the rest of the Monastery (and the Perl community), at first, Perl6 items should be clearly labeled as such. Eventually, Perl5 items will also require clear labels. And after that, Perl6 items will no longer require labels.

"perl6" and "perl5" (no spaces) are good markers. Put them in brackets of some kind if desired. "use 6.0" and "use 5.0" are also good markers in my book. "use v6" and "use 6" are much less clear, in my book. Even "use v6.0" is less clear to me. I'd like "use strict" to be a Perl5 marker and asked Larry to make it so, but I never saw a response.

[davido] 2004-01-18:

I agree that 'clever' answers often don't answer the actual question. Perl 6-ish responses to Perl 5 questions are generally useless as "Q and A Answers" in a P5-centric forum. They may be interesting fodder for discussion, but I feel that the QandA section's "charter" is to provide answers to common questions, not discussion. A Perl 6 response to a Perl 5 question is not an answer. It is an unfortunate side-effect that it gets labled an Answer by our system. It is the QandAEditors responsibility to see that answers in QandA are on topic, accurate, clean, and effective.

The Monastery has other areas more appropriate for open discussion. SoPW, and Meditations come to my mind immediately as areas where the discussion of Perl 6 solutions to common Perl 5 questions might be on-topic.

As for how to ensure that P6-ish answers get listed after P5 answers, that's simply not possible, since QandA Answers are ordered by reputation, not by the nature of the content.

So for now, I oppose P6 answers in QandA, unless they are in direct response to P6 questions (of which I know of none). P6 is not clearly defined, behaviors will change, such answers aren't applicable to the here-and-now of P5, they encourage discussion rather than resolution, and therefore, aren't QandA Answers.

I'm still open for comments.

[ysth], 2004-01-18:

The question of perl6 answers (in the absence of even an alpha perl6) I think leads to the more general question of "clever" answers. I see a spectrum of answerss in the range practical..clever (eq impractical) to some questions. A perl6 answer is just an extreme case of impracticality. The case for leaving such answers in place is that they may lead readers to learn interesting things not directly related to the question at hand. The challenge is making sure the practical answers are shown first, especially since a "clever" answer may draw more votes. Is there a good mechanism in place for enforcing order?

[davido], 2004-01-17:

A day or so ago [ysth] and I both pondered over the appropriateness of Perl-6ish "Answers" in the Q&A section. The node that prompted the discussion was [id://321712]. In my opinion, the answer does nothing for Perl 5.x.x users, and is speculative, since P6 has yet to be released (and may not come for quite awhile still). Thus, the response has little or no value as an "Answer", and thus, little or no place in the [Catagorized Questions and Answers] section. Also, since P6 hasn't been finalized and released, it's doubtful that the [QandAEditors] themselves have devoted enough time to learning Perl 6 to be competant to verify the accuracy of Perl 6ish Answers. I'm open to hear other opinions and thoughts. For now, the node is left untouched, until I (we, including [ysth]) hear arguments supporting or opposing the deletion of this and similar nodes as they crop up.

Only [vroom] can reparent nodes so far. There is a tool for [editors] to reparent nodes but it doesn't work very well yet and likely won't work for Cat Q+A for quite a while after it works for regular nodes. So I suggest someone just post an answer that contains the contents of the reply (or a combination of the previous answer and the reply, or update the existing answer to incorporate the reply, or whatever). The point of Cat Q+A is that the answer should be "the best" answers so heavy editing is a good thing. Then request [editors] purge the reply, then Q+A Editors can purge the original answer if needed.

The replies to Cat Q+A are not very visible and so you shouldn't worry about them much other than making sure that any important information in the reply gets incorporated into one of the answers. If a cat Q+A generates lots of replies, then it might mean it should be SoPWified.
